lg.l: Lyk A pilgreme which þ[at] goth on ffote
And hath non hors to releue his t[ra]uaile
Hote drye werey I ffynde may no bote
Off well colde whan þrust hym doth assaile
Wyn nor lico[ur] thatt may to hym auaile
Right so ffaire I which in my busynesse
No socoure ffynde my rudenesse to redresse
¶ I mene as thus I haue no ffreysh lico[ur]
Oute off the conduitis off caliope
Nor þrough clieo in retorik no ffloure
In my laboure ffor to reffreysh me
Nor off the the sustren in no[um]bre þries thre
Which w[ith] cithera on pernaso duell
They neuer I me gaue drynke onys off the[r] well
¶ Nor off þe[r] sprynges clere and cristallyne
Thatt sprange by touchyng off the pegasie
Theire ffauo[ur] lakkith my makyng to enlimyne
I ffynde þe[r] baume off so grete scarcite
To tame þe[r] tonnes w[ith] soume drope of plente
Ffor poliphemus þrough his grete blyndenesse
Hath in me derked off argus the brightnesse
¶ Oure liff here shortt off witt the grete dulnesse
The heuy soule troubled w[ith] t[ra]uaile
And off memorie the glacyng brotelnesse
Drede and onkounnyng haue made a strong bataile
W[ith] werinesse my spirite to assaile
And w[ith] their subtill crepyng in most queyntt
Haue made my sprite in my makyng ffor to feyntt
¶ And ou[er]more the ffereffull ffrowardnesse
Off my stepmodir callid oblyuyoun
Hath made a bastile off fforyetilnesse
To stoppe the passage and shadowe my resoun
Thatt I my[ght] haue no clere direccioun
In t[ra]nslatyng off newe to quyk me
Stories to write off olde antiquite
¶ Thus was I sett and stode in double were
Att the metyng off ffereffull weyis
The ton was this who eu[er] list to lere
Wher as god will gan me constreyne
Bochas to accomplish ffor to do my peyne
Came ignorance w[ith] a mase off drede
My penne to arest I du[r]st nott procede
¶ Thus by my selff reme[m]bring on this boke
I to translate hou I had undirtake
Ffull pale off chere astonyd in my loke
Myn hande gan tremble my pen I feltt quake
Thatt dispeirid I had almost fforsake
So grete a laboure dredefull [and] inportabill
Itt to p[ar]forme I ffounde my selff so onabill
¶ Twene the residue off this grete iourne
And litill partt þ[er] off was begoun
I stode chek mate ffor ffere whan I gan se
In my wey how litill I had ronne
Like to aman þ[at] ffailid day and sonne
And had no light to accomplish his viage
So ffe[re] I stode abak in my passage
¶ The nyght came on dirkid w[ith] ignorance
My witt was dull my clerenesse to discerne
In retorik ffor lak off sufficiaunce
The torches oute and queyntt was the lat[er]ne
And in this caas my stile to gou[er]ne
Me ffor to ffurther I ffounde non oþ[er] muse
Butt hard as stone periedese [and] meduse
¶ Supportt was non my dulnesse ffor to guye
Pou[er]tt approchid in stale crokid age
Mercurie absentt and philologie
My purs ay light and uoide off all couinage
Bachus ffe[re] off to gladde my corage
An ebbe off plente skarcite att full
Which off an olde man makith the spirite dull
¶ Butt hope and trust to putt awey dispeire
In to my mynde off newe gan hem dresse
And cheffe off all to make the wedir ffaire
My lordis ffredome and bounteuous largesse
In to my hertt brought in such gladnesse
Thatt þrough releuyng off his benyngne g[ra]ce
Ffals indigence list me no mo[re] manace
¶ A hou it is an hertly reioysyng
To s[er]ue a prince þ[at] list to adu[er]tise
Off þe[r] s[er]uauntes þ[e] feythfull iust menyng
And list concidre to guerdon þe[r] s[er]uise
And att nede list hem nott dispise
Butt ffrom all daunge[re] þ[at] should hem noye [...]
Ben eu[er] redy to helpe hem and releue
And thus releuyd by the goodlihede
And þrough the noblesse of th[i]s most knyghtly man
All mystes clerid off dispere and drede
Trust hope and ffaith in to myn hertt ran
And on my labor anon ffurthw[i]t[h] I gan
Ffor by clere supportt off my lordis gr[a]ce
All fforeyn lettyng ffro me I did enchase
Ffolkes thatt ese to make grete viages
Which endirffonge longe traile and labor
Whan they gane haue done grete part off ther passage
Off werinesse to asswagen ther rigor
Agayn ffeyntise to ffynde some ffauor
Loke offte ageyn parcell to be releuyd
To sene how moch ther jorney [i]s achevid
Cause why they so offte loke ageyn
Bakward tue loke and eke visage
Is only this thatt itt may be seyn
To them how moch is done off ther viage
Eke weri ffolke th[a]t gone on pilgremage
Rest hem sumwhile a ffull large space
Laborous swete to wype ffrom ther fface
Ther hevy ffardell among thei cast adown
Att certen boundes to do ther bakkis ease
Att wellis colde eke offt entencion
Drinke freyth watis ther g[r]evous thurst to apese
Or holsom wynes ther appetite to plese
Rekenyng the myles by co[m]putacions
Which they haue passed off castell and off touns
Itt doth them ease the nombre ffor to knowe
Sith they began off many grete jurneys
Off high mountenys and off valis lowe
And straunge sightts passyng by cout [crossed out] co[n]treis
The bukouth bildyng off boroughis and citeis
Countyng the distaunce ffro townes and the spaces
This is ther talking att ther restyng places
And semblably Iohn Bochas as I ffynde
Gan t[ur]ne his bak loke and countenance
And to remembre apoyntid in his mynde
To the stories rehersid in substance
In his two boks off sorow [and] displesaunce
Hym selff astonyd m[er]uelyng a grete dele
The ffall off p[r]inc[is] ffro ffortune is whele
Off þe[r] onhappe as he doth reherce
Toward hym selff the cause doth rebounde
Their clymbyng up the hevenys forr to p[er]ce
In worldly richesseis to encresyn and habounde
Their gredy etik doth hem selff conffounde
And theire thurst off hauyng onstauncheable
Causeth þe[r] noblesse to be so variable
High clymbyng up off reson who so can se
Dulleth off brayins the memoriall
Bluntith the sight in high and lowe degre
Which ffrom a loffte makith he[m] to haue afall
Men seyn off olde who þ[at] coueyte all
Att onsettt houre suche on[e] shall nott chese
Butt all his gaderyng atonys he shall lese
Ffor worldly ffolk which so high arise
W[ith] the grete peys off worldly habundaunce
And w[ith] the weight off ffroward covetise
Namely wher ffortune holdith the balaunce
W[ith] onware t[ur]ne off sum onhappy chaunce
This stormy quene this double ffals goddesse
Plungeth þem doun ffrom all þe[r] richesse
Whereffore Bochas here off here off to make a p[re]eff
Serchith to p[ur]pos a sentence ffull notable
A clere example off onware such my scheffe
Writt off an autor by man[er] off a ffable
Albe the menyng be ffull comendable
And wele accordyng in conclusion
To the clere p[ur]pos off his entencion
Touching þis>tarquyn of whom I now tolde
As myn auctor makith mencioun
he called was tarquynius the olde
Which longe in rome had dominaciou[n]
Till his kynrede and generaciou[n]
For the offence done onto lucrece
Causid off kyngis the name for to ceese
For his sonne which affter gan[n] succede
For his outrages and his extorcions
And for many anoþer cruell dede
For his hatefull usurpacions
His foward liff and fals condicions
Among the people both still and loude
He callid was tarquynyus the proude
Full obstinatt he was in his ententt
Ambicious to Acroche grete riches
Till that fortune wax inpacientt
Agayns hym in all his grete nobles
Gan hir snares and his crokes dresse
Thought she wold butt he kepte hym wele
All sodenly cast hym ffrom hir whele
A sonne he had vicious as I ffynde
To all virtue most contr[a]rious
To be frowned it came to hym off kynde
And off nature proude [and] dispetuous
Agenys the peple fell and malicious
Natt louyd butt drad for tyranye of right
Is thing most hatid in the peple is sight
This proude Tarquynu[s] þe story is wele kouth
Agenys lucrece a grete outrage
Oppresid hir beaute in his unbridelid youth
Hir trouthe assailyng in a ffurious rage
For which his fadir he and his lenage
Expilid wern and for this hatefull þing
Ther was neu[er] aft[er] in rome crownyd kyng
His body corupte she clere off hert [and] þought
By force assailid was hir Innocence
Oppresid hir beaute butt her spirite nought
Hir chast will did non offence
Butt entred is into hir concience
A grete remors for all his wyfly trouth
To sleen hir selff which was to grete a routh
And for that Bochas remembreth petuously
Hir dedely sorwe and lamentaciou[n]
Writt hir compleyntt in ordre ceriously
Which that she made ffor his oppresioun
I folwe must and make mencioun
Afft[er] myne auto[r] parcell rehersyng
Touchyng hir wordis seide in her dieyng
All be it so by byddyng off my lord
Rehersid haue in my t[ra]nslacioun
Afft[er] pierius have and þ[ere] a word
Off a full dolefull declamaciou[n]

choice.sic: And þough I can nott folaw his entenciou[n]
I shall swe the trouth off rehersyng
choice.corr: For his sake men mythe seen and rede

choice.sic: As in substaunce the effecte off his writyng
choice.corr: What wifli trouthe was in his womanheede

lg.l: And Iohn Bochas list nott sett a side
Butt þ[at] he wolde rehersen in sentence
Hir Wofull co[m]pleyntt and þ[er] uppon abyde
Off wrong[is] done to hir Innocence
And though I can nott ffolow his eloquence

choice.sic: As in substance the effecte off this writyng
choice.corr: I shal sue the trouthe off rehersyng

choice.sic: To you I shall make full rehersyng
choice.corr: As in substaunce theffect off his writyng

lg.l: The morwe nexttnext afftir þ[i]s ffoule dede
Lucrece up roos w[i]t[h] a ffull dedely chere
Oute off his face goon was all the rede
And dirked wern her hevenly eyen clere
All clad in blak afft[er] the manere
Off thilke ffolke which in especiall
Arn wont to goon to ffestis funerall
All hir frendis beyng in p[re]sence
Housbonde fadre w[ith] oþ[er] eke also
By and by rehersyng in sentence
The c[ir]cumstaunce of hir hertly wo
Vnder hope my lord will me support
What that she seide I will to you report
[[F]]or as moch q[uo]d she as I Lucrece
Am by the law ioyned in mariage
To the my lord who loue shall ay encrece
Towardis the w[ith] all the surplusage
Of wifly trouth to enduren all myn age
As humble subiet w[ith] feithfull obeysaunce
Vndre thy lordship and thy gov[er]naunce
O Collatyn my lord and t[re]we housbonde
Best belouyd of hoole affection
I will no more no quarell take on hande
Nor in no wise make non accion
W[ith]oute þ[at] þ[ou] list enclyne adown
Goodly thyn eeris to yeue me audience
To that I shall reherce in thy p[re]sence
Iniurie done or any man[ner] wrong
Agayn my worship or myn honeste
By the lawe my sentence is made strong
It toucheth you as wele as me
I am so hooly yolden vnto the
Thou art my hede who cleerly can discerne
Lord and housbonde my body to gov[er]ne
Parciall causis in soth þ[er] may no[n] be
Atwene vs tweyne nor no disseu[er]aunce
For soote and bitt[er] ioye and adu[er]site
We must hem weye both in o balance
Count[er]peise our sorowis our plesaunce
Entermedele all þing þ[at] is in dowte
Receyve oure fortune as it comyth aboute
Ther may atwene us be no menyng double
But on hert on will and o corage
And as a woman þ[at] stondeth now in trouble
W[ith]outen polishyng of any feire langage
I mote disclosen to you the grete out[ra]ge
Doon unto me and pleynly it discure
Which to redresse lyith hooly in yo[ur] cure
For the mat[er] to speke in wordis pleyn
Aright oute serchid and the trouth oute founde
As a iust cause indefferent to tweyne
Toward vs both the quarell doth rebounde
And more strongly oure mat[er] for to grounde
Reherce I will so that ye sauff it vouch
A mortal wrong which þ[e] and me doth touch
In a castell which callid is Collace
Of which my lord here hath the gov[er]naunce
Tarquyn the young came into þ[at] place
I full disware to make p[er]viaunce
Agayn his comyng or any ordenaunce
Toforn not warned of his officers
Sate vnp[er]ueyid among my chamberers
Of entent to eschwe[n] idilnes
We sate and span vpon wollis softe
For she of vices is a chefe mastres
Wher she is cherished and i set alofte
But of custome as I haue do full ofte
I and my women dwly as we oughte
To avoide slouth full besely wroughte
His entering was meke and debonaire
Benyugne of port of loke [and] of visage
W[ith] a p[re]tence of many wordis faire
In whois menyng was full grete out[ra]ge
his chere co[n]trarie vnto his corage
In this wise þ[er] he was receyvid
Wherby alas i falsly was deceyvid
At p[ri]me face as me þought it due
I hym receyvid at his in comyng
Roos vp mekely and gan hym to salue
As it aperteynyd in all man[er] þing
Vnto the soune of a worthy kyng
And truly Tarquyn for which I sey alas
Me to betraye stode in the same caas
A kyng[e]s soune should of duete
Bene to women wall and p[ro]teccion
P[re]s[er]ue and kepe hem in all suerte
That no man shoulde of no p[re]sumpcion
Doon hem no wronge nor opp[re]ssion
Rather deye þan see hem suffer vnright
Av[er]tisyng the office of a knyght
But in cont[ra]rie off knyghthode he hath wrought
By ffals outrage done agayns me
Wrong weyes [and] croked menys sought
Off lawes tweyne to breke the liberte
And difface the Autorite
Off lawe Cyuile and naturall also
In my p[er]sone offendyng both twotoo
ffirst by fals subtile compassyng
He gan espie the weyesthestris off the place
And whan abedde Alone I laye slepyng
like A lion ffull sterne off loke and fface
W[ith] his leffthonde my throte he did enbrace
And In his other helde agayn all lawe
Me ffor to opp[re]sse a nakid swerd I drawe
Thus afforcyng my wifly chastite
Ageyn knyghthode he did this grete offence
My liff my worship putt in p[er]plexite
Hauyng no myght to make resistence
Me manasyng by dedely violence
The toon off tweyne to deye in his ententt
Or to avoutry ffalsly to consentt
Thus I stode soole Atwene deth [and] diffame
My body corupte my spirite abode clene
My spousaile broke and my good name
